required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Together We Can Against Alcohol Tobacco and Drug Use: A Feasibility Trial With Latino Immigrant Youth
clinical_study.official_title: Juntos Against Alcohol Tobacco and Drug Use Intervention Trial

collaborator.agency: National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS)

brief_summary.textblock:
Adolescent alcohol tobacco and drug (ATOD) use is a major public health concern, with rates for Latino middle school youth higher than other ethnic groups. One well-established precursor of adolescent ATOD use is psychosocial stress. The overall aim of this project is to test the efficacy of a culturally appropriate psychosocial program to prevent or reduce ATOD use among Latino immigrant youth (ages 13 to 16). The intervention consists of: (1) encouraging parental involvement in child schooling, general parenting skills, and coping strategies ; (2) fostering child social emotional learning (SEL) through assigning a near-peer success coach to help develop critical thinking, problem solving, and goal setting skills; and (3) promoting positive peer affiliations through participation in regular activities that facilitate bonding to prosocial institutions. The three specific aims are:
1. Evaluate the efficacy of the intervention to delay the initiation into or reduce ATOD use among Latino adolescents with one or more undocumented parent.
2. Evaluate the efficacy of the intervention in reducing stress exposure in youth and parents
3. Evaluate the impact of the intervention on strengthening known protective factors, specifically child SEL and parent-child, peer, and school relationships and the role of these factors as buffers against stress.
The study's primary hypothesis is: The Unidos Se Puede program will delay initiation of ATOD use of current non-users or reduce use among current users.

detailed_description.textblock:
Adolescent alcohol tobacco and drug (ATOD) use is a major public health concern, with rates for Latino middle school youth higher than other ethnic groups. One well-established precursor of adolescent ATOD use is psychosocial stress. The overall aim of this project is to test the efficacy of a culturally appropriate psychosocial program to prevent or reduce ATOD use among Latino immigrant youth (ages 13 to 16). The intervention consists of: (1) encouraging parental involvement in child schooling, general parenting skills, and coping strategies ; (2) fostering child social emotional learning (SEL) through assigning a near-peer success coach to help develop critical thinking, problem solving, and goal setting skills; and (3) promoting positive peer affiliations through participation in regular activities that facilitate bonding to prosocial institutions. The three specific aims are:
1. Evaluate the efficacy of the intervention to delay the initiation into or reduce ATOD use among Latino adolescents with one or more undocumented parent.
2. Evaluate the efficacy of the intervention in reducing stress exposure in youth and parents
3. Evaluate the impact of the intervention on strengthening known protective factors, specifically child SEL and parent-child, peer, and school relationships and the role of these factors as buffers against stress.
The study's primary hypothesis is: The Unidos Se Puede program will delay initiation of ATOD use of current non-users or reduce use among current users.
Two cohorts of Latino youth and their parents (n=200 dyads each (n=100 treatment and n=100 control); N=400 dyad) with staggered start dates will be recruited from a random sample of Latino 7th graders and screened for inclusion/exclusion criteria. Those meeting the criteria and agreeing to participate will provide baseline data before being randomly assigned to either the treatment or control condition. Participants will be followed for 30 months (beginning of 7th grade (baseline), end of 7th, 8th, and 9th grades). The study will collect psychosocial measures and biomarker data, used to create an objective measure of stress and ATOD use.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Two cohorts of Latino youth and their parents (n=200 dyads each (n=100 treatment and n=100 control); N=400 dyad) with staggered start dates will be recruited from a random sample of Latino 7th graders and screened for inclusion/exclusion criteria. Those meeting the criteria and agreeing to participate will provide baseline data before being randomly assigned to either the treatment or control condition. Participants will be followed for 30 months (beginning of 7th grade (baseline), end of 7th, 8th, and 9th grades). The study will collect psychosocial measures and biomarker data, used to create an objective measure of stress and ATOD use.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in past 30-day ATOD use (alcohol, tobacco, marijuana)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, and 6 months, 18 months and 30 months post-baseline
primary_outcome.description: The ATOD outcome measure creates a single index of use by summing youth report of the frequency of their use during the past 30 days for each of the following substance: alcohol, tobacco and marijuana.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, and 6 months, 18 months and 30 months post-baseline
secondary_outcome.description: The allostatic load measure creates a single index of exposure to chronic stress by averaging the z-scores of each of the following parameters: salivary cortisol (difference in AM to PM levels), hair cortisol, C Reactive Protein, Interluken-1RA, systolic pressure, diastolic pressure, BMI (ratio of weight to height i.e., kg/m^2), waist circumference and waist to hip ratio, and heart rate variability (variability between successive heart beats in milliseconds).

arm_group.description: Unidos Se Puede: consists of 5-weekly Family Workshops, 15 monthly booster sessions, 14-months success coaching, adolescent group activities and will be compared to an attention placebo control.
Placebo consists of 24 financial planning classes for parents and youth.

intervention.description: The intervention consists of: (1) encouraging parental involvement in child schooling, general parenting skills, and coping strategies ; (2) fostering child social emotional learning (SEL) through assigning a near-peer success coach to help develop critical thinking, problem solving, and goal setting skills; and (3) promoting positive peer affiliations through participation in regular activities that facilitate bonding to prosocial institutions.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Self-identified as Latino (Hispanic),
- Spanish as the primary language spoken in home,
- Enrolled in 7th grade in public school at one of the target sites.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Currently undergoing mental health treatment,
- Not eligible to take end of year examinations due to cognitive limitations.

patient_data.ipd_description: The intent to share data with other researchers exists, however, a plan to do so has not yet been developed.
